pr_title: Update the JMS guide to use the Qpid JMS extension

timeline.bodyText: The two or Docker are weird. This should be reworded.
timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -19,26 +21,40 @@ To complete this guide, you need:
 * an IDE
 * JDK 1.8+ installed with `JAVA_HOME` configured appropriately
 * Apache Maven 3.5.3+
-* A running Artemis server, or Docker Compose to start one
-* GraalVM installed if you want to run in native mode.
+* A running Artemis server, or Docker to start one
+* GraalVM, or Docker, installed if you want to run in native mode.

replies.bodyText: Any recommendations? I couldn't really think of a better wording as they are really separate things. You dont need Docker for either requirement, but you could use it for one or both of them. Other guides seem to just ignore that you can use docker for native builds and so you dont need GraalVM installed.
replies.author: gemmellr

replies.bodyText: Ah no, it's OK, I somehow missed it was a bullet point.
replies.author: gsmet

timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -19,26 +21,40 @@ To complete this guide, you need:
 * an IDE
 * JDK 1.8+ installed with `JAVA_HOME` configured appropriately
 * Apache Maven 3.5.3+
-* A running Artemis server, or Docker Compose to start one
-* GraalVM installed if you want to run in native mode.
+* A running Artemis server, or Docker to start one
+* GraalVM, or Docker, installed if you want to run in native mode.
 
 == Architecture
 
 In this guide, we are going to generate (random) prices in one component.
-These prices are written in an JMS queue (`prices`).
-Another component reads from the `prices` queue and stores the last price.
-The data can be fetch from a browser using a fetch button from a JAX-RS resource.
+These prices are written to a queue (`prices`) using a JMS client.
+Another component reads from the `prices` queue and stores the latest price.
+The data can be fetched from a browser using a fetch button from a JAX-RS resource.
+
+
+The guide can be used either via the Apache Qpid JMS AMQP client as detailed immediately below, or
+alternatively with the Apache ActiveMQ Artemis JMS client given some some different configuration

 ./mvnw package -Pnative

-== Configuration Reference
+Or, if you dont have GraalVM installed, you can instead use Docker to build the native executable using:

timeline.author: gsmet
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -290,6 +319,83 @@ You can build the native executable with:
 ./mvnw package -Pnative
 ----
 
-== Configuration Reference
+Or, if you dont have GraalVM installed, you can instead use Docker to build the native executable using:
+[source, shell]
+----
+./mvnw package -Pnative -Dquarkus.native.container-build=true
+----
+
+and then run with:
+
+[source, shell]
+----
+./target/jms-quickstart-1.0-SNAPSHOT-runner
+----
+
+Open `http://localhost:8080/prices.html` in your browser.
+
+'''

replies.bodyText: A line separator between the two outer client sections to make it a little more obvious this is the end of the steps.
replies.author: gemmellr

timeline.message: update the JMS guide, use the Qpid JMS extension but still detail using the Artemis JMS extension
